“Volunteer Emergency Medical Service Has Exceeded Capacity/ Appeal for International Humanitarian Groups for Support and Aid”

The Hong Kong Police has caused a large number of injuries from the beatings, massive scale of tear gas releases and use of rubber bullets since June 12. Alfred Wong of Medecins Inspires (a concern group formed by Hong Kong medical professionals) is concerned that the number of injured people seeking help from the Group’s support hotline is comparable to the total number of patients visiting the A&E department of a small scale hospital. Many of the injured parties choose the hotline over going to a public hospitals because of the white terror campaign and fear of being searched and arrested at the hospital. We are witnessing a critical humanitarian crisis.

Medecins Inspires set up two lines in June, one of which supports people with physical injuries. Various degrees of injuries have been reported, ranging from those requiring operations with the assistance of the group. Details of the operations cannot be disclosed. The majority of the injured people hesitated to seek help from either the public or private hospitals. Alfred Wong explained, “they contacted us because there had been incidents of private hospitals reporting the injured to the police and the police launching arrests inside public hospital wards, causing worries that even visiting a private clinic might not be safe.”

Wong also pointed out, a small number of patients came for a third party medical examination report to prepare for possible litigations against the police because they were beaten up the police cars or police stations after their arrest.

The group’s other hotline provides psychological support. The number of protestors on the verge of nervous breakdowns is not insignificant. However, related support at the community level is sparse, and again they are scared to seek help from hospitals or clinics.

Wong disclosed that the number of people reaching out to hotline is comparable to the cases handled by the A&E department of a small scale hospital. Wong didn’t disclose the actual number but was convinced that the actual number of injured people is way larger than the official figure released by the government.

With the capacity of the volunteer A&E service maxed out, Wong said humanitarian challenges in war zones are more conspicuous because tanks and military road blocks preventing people from accessing hospitals are more visible, and international rescue groups will set up hospitals in these places. The problem in Hong Kong is not as visible, as it’s white terror instead of tanks that is preventing injured people from seeking help from proper medical channels.

According to Wong, the adverse impact on Hong Kong people is indiscriminate. The police are releasing tear gas in railway stations, affecting the general public. Clinics in areas affected by tear gas and conflicts between police and citizens close early, making medical service unavailable to normal people who are not involved in the protests. This too is a humanitarian concern.

Alfred Wong stated that Medecins Inspires is short of manpower. To ensure the highest degree of confidentiality, there are under 10 hotline agents, all required to be existing members of the Group. While maintaining the effective operations of the hotline, the team of hotline agents suffer from serious exhaustion. “We are uncertain how long we can sustain the support service or how long the team can last,” said a member from the counselling team who himself also suffer severe psychological pressure. “It’s hard to personally handle the many depressing stories I’ve listened to. Some of us have expressed our own potential mental breakdown,”he continued. Wong pleaded international groups to send delegates to Hong Kong to offer emergency medical support.

Meanwhile, it’s vital for the Hong Kong police to stop the brutal beatings, and the indiscriminate arrests and assaults on citizens.
